Dear ___,

We are writing to provide a summary of your recent hospital stay from February 10, 2024, to February 14, 2024. You were admitted to our facility with symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon admission, these symptoms were indicative of pneumonia, and a diagnosis of lobar pneumonia was confirmed, specifically affecting the left lower lobe, as detailed by the chest X-ray findings.

During your hospitalization, your initial laboratory results revealed an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) of 60 mg/L, an increased white blood cell count (WBC) of 12 x10^9/L, and normal hemoglobin and platelet levels. You were treated with empirical antibiotics, specifically amoxicillin administered intravenously at 500 mg every 8 hours.

As you progressed through your hospital stay, your clinical condition showed significant improvement. By February 11, 2024, your CRP levels had decreased to 50 mg/L, and your WBCs showed a slight improvement at 11 x10^9/L. In response to your progress, the amoxicillin dose was adjusted to 250 mg IV daily, alongside other medications including paracetamol as needed and atorvastatin 20 mg to be taken nightly.

On February 12, 2024, further improvement in your condition was noted. Your temperature normalized at 37°C, and your oxygen saturation improved to 96%. Correspondingly, the decision was made to transition you to oral antibiotics, and you showed no adverse reactions to the current treatment regimen.

By February 13, 2024, your CRP levels had decreased significantly to 20 mg/L, and your WBC count returned closer to the normal range at 7 x10^9/L. As a result, the medical team considered you ready for discharge planning, with your condition being stable and improved.

At the time of your discharge on February 14, 2024, your vital signs were stable with a normal temperature, heart rate, and satisfactory oxygen saturation. You were discharged with instructions to continue with oral amoxicillin 250 mg daily for an additional five days. It is important that you adhere to this medication regimen to ensure complete recovery.

As part of your ongoing care, we recommend returning to the outpatient clinic for a follow-up appointment in two weeks to evaluate your recovery progress and ensure there are no residual signs of infection.

We extend our appreciation for your cooperation during your hospital stay and wish you a smooth recovery. Should you have any immediate concerns or notice a return or worsening of symptoms, please contact our clinic or seek medical attention promptly.

Warm regards,

Dr. ___  
Resident Physician
